content.verbatim_text: It is fairly common to specify the purpose by in e.g. stating the purpose will be the discussions between the parties with respect to certain supplier products or services.
content.plain_text: A common purpose definition is 'discussions between parties regarding certain supplier products or services'.
content.expert_insight: This provides an example of a typical, but potentially restrictive, purpose definition. It serves as a warning that such phrasing might be too narrow for Zebracorp's broader business needs.
content.justification: Provides an example of a common purpose definition.
content.implication_company: Illustrates a definition that Zebracorp might encounter and need to modify.
content.implication_supplier: Shows a common, often preferred, narrow definition from their perspective.
content.text: It is fairly common to specify the purpose by in e.g. stating the purpose will be the discussions between the parties with respect to certain supplier products or services.

content.verbatim_text: Such a definition of purpose may substantially limit Zebracorp’s ability to use the information in Direct Procurement where Zebracorp is essentially distributing the supplier products to its own customers.
content.plain_text: A narrow purpose definition could severely restrict Zebracorp's use of information in direct procurement, especially when distributing supplier products to its own customers.
content.expert_insight: This highlights a specific business risk for Zebracorp. A narrow purpose could inadvertently prevent Zebracorp from sharing necessary information with its own customers, hindering its distribution model.
content.justification: Explains the negative implication of a narrow purpose definition for Zebracorp's business model.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp needs to avoid such narrow definitions to protect its direct procurement and distribution capabilities.
content.implication_supplier: They should be aware that Zebracorp has specific business needs that require a broader purpose.
content.text: Such a definition of purpose may substantially limit Zebracorp’s ability to use the information in Direct Procurement where Zebracorp is essentially distributing the supplier products to its own customers.

content.verbatim_text: In a supplier contract, it may for this reason, be worthwhile to specify that the purpose of the NDA will be in e.g. to enable Zebracorp to purchase the products/services of the supplier for further resale and distribution to its own customers.
content.plain_text: In supplier contracts, it's advisable to define the NDA's purpose to explicitly allow Zebracorp to purchase supplier products/services for resale and distribution to its customers.
content.expert_insight: This provides a specific, recommended phrasing for the purpose clause that directly addresses Zebracorp's business model, ensuring it has the necessary rights to operate effectively.
content.justification: Offers a specific strategic recommendation for drafting the purpose clause.
content.implication_company: Ensures Zebracorp's ability to conduct its core business activities (resale and distribution) without breaching confidentiality.
content.implication_supplier: Clarifies Zebracorp's intended use of their products/services and associated information.
content.text: In a supplier contract, it may for this reason, be worthwhile to specify that the purpose of the NDA will be in e.g. to enable Zebracorp to purchase the products/services of the supplier for further resale and distribution to its own customers.

content.verbatim_text: A narrower definition of the purpose of the NDA may not entitle Zebracorp to share necessary supplier information to its customers.
content.plain_text: A narrow NDA purpose might prevent Zebracorp from sharing essential supplier information with its customers.
content.expert_insight: This reiterates the direct consequence of a restrictive purpose clause, emphasizing the potential operational paralysis if Zebracorp cannot provide its customers with necessary product details.
content.justification: Explains a specific negative implication of a narrow purpose definition.
content.implication_company: Highlights the risk of operational hindrance if the purpose is not broad enough.
content.implication_supplier: They should understand Zebracorp's need to share information with its end-customers.
content.text: A narrower definition of the purpose of the NDA may not entitle Zebracorp to share necessary supplier information to its customers.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp must have a specific right to disclose information to its affiliated entities (i.e. entities belonging to the same corporate group) and typically also to its other subcontractors, external contractors, consultants, advisors and customers.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp requires the explicit right to disclose confidential information to its affiliates, subcontractors, external contractors, consultants, advisors, and customers.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical operational requirement for any large organization. Without explicit rights to share with its ecosystem, Zebracorp's ability to function and collaborate would be severely hampered.
content.justification: States a non-negotiable requirement for Zebracorp regarding disclosure rights.
content.implication_company: Ensures Zebracorp can operate effectively by sharing information with necessary internal and external parties.
content.implication_supplier: They must grant Zebracorp these disclosure rights, subject to standard conditions.
content.text: Zebracorp must have a specific right to disclose information to its affiliated entities (i.e. entities belonging to the same corporate group) and typically also to its other subcontractors, external contractors, consultants, advisors and customers.

content.verbatim_text: In most cases such right can also be extended to the subcontractors of the selling party.
content.plain_text: The right to disclose information can often be extended to the selling party's subcontractors.
content.expert_insight: This notes a common reciprocal provision. While Zebracorp demands this right for itself, it acknowledges that the counterparty may also require similar rights for its own ecosystem.
content.justification: Provides information on common reciprocal disclosure rights.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should anticipate and be prepared to grant similar rights to the supplier, subject to appropriate safeguards.
content.implication_supplier: They can expect to negotiate for similar rights to disclose to their own subcontractors.
content.text: In most cases such right can also be extended to the subcontractors of the selling party.

content.verbatim_text: The right to disclose to such third parties is practically always made subject to each of those third parties reasonably having a need to know such information, and subject to such third parties agreeing to be bound to confidentiality in writing to an extent not less stringent than the obligations imposed on the receiving party.
content.plain_text: Disclosure to third parties is almost always conditional on a 'need-to-know' basis and the third parties agreeing to confidentiality obligations no less stringent than those of the receiving party.
content.expert_insight: These are standard and essential safeguards for third-party disclosures. The 'need-to-know' principle limits access, and the 'no less stringent' requirement ensures a consistent level of protection down the chain.
content.justification: Explains the standard conditions for third-party disclosures.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure these conditions are met when disclosing information to its own third parties.
content.implication_supplier: They will be expected to adhere to these conditions when disclosing Zebracorp's information to their third parties.
content.text: The right to disclose to such third parties is practically always made subject to each of those third parties reasonably having a need to know such information, and subject to such third parties agreeing to be bound to confidentiality in writing to an extent not less stringent than the obligations imposed on the receiving party.

content.verbatim_text: Whenever Zebracorp gives this right to the supplier, we should require that such right to disclose is limited to named sub-suppliers of the supplier only.
content.plain_text: When Zebracorp grants disclosure rights to a supplier, it should insist that these rights are limited to specifically named sub-suppliers.
content.expert_insight: This is a crucial control mechanism. Limiting disclosure to *named* sub-suppliers provides Zebracorp with transparency and control over who ultimately receives its confidential information, especially for sensitive data.
content.justification: Provides a specific negotiation requirement for Zebracorp when granting disclosure rights.
content.implication_company: Maintains control and transparency over who has access to Zebracorp's confidential information.
content.implication_supplier: They would need to identify and potentially get approval for each sub-supplier to whom they wish to disclose information.
content.text: Whenever Zebracorp gives this right to the supplier, we should require that such right to disclose is limited to named sub-suppliers of the supplier only.

content.verbatim_text: This is particularly important in R&D collaboration where Zebracorp gives out product technical specifications and other sensitive information of our products.
content.plain_text: This limitation on disclosure is especially vital in R&D collaborations involving sensitive product technical specifications.
content.expert_insight: This justifies the previous tactic by highlighting the increased risk in R&D contexts. The sensitivity of the information necessitates tighter controls over its dissemination.
content.justification: Explains the rationale and importance of the previous tactic in specific scenarios.
content.implication_company: Reinforces the need for strict control over sensitive R&D information.
content.implication_supplier: They should understand the heightened sensitivity of information in R&D contexts.
content.text: This is particularly important in R&D collaboration where Zebracorp gives out product technical specifications and other sensitive information of our products.

content.verbatim_text: In any event such right to share confidential information to third parties should be conditional on the receiving party accepting responsibility for any unauthorized disclosure or use of the confidential information by such third party to the same extent, as if it had been its own unauthorized disclosure or use of information.
content.plain_text: Any right to share confidential information with third parties must be conditional on the receiving party accepting full responsibility for any unauthorized disclosure or use by those third parties.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical 'flow-down' liability clause. It ensures that the primary receiving party remains fully accountable for the actions of its downstream recipients, preventing a dilution of responsibility.
content.justification: States a mandatory condition for granting third-party disclosure rights.
content.implication_company: Protects Zebracorp by ensuring the primary contracting party remains liable for its third parties' actions.
content.implication_supplier: They must accept full liability for any breaches by their permitted third parties.
content.text: In any event such right to share confidential information to third parties should be conditional on the receiving party accepting responsibility for any unauthorized disclosure or use of the confidential information by such third party to the same extent, as if it had been its own unauthorized disclosure or use of information.

content.verbatim_text: The duration of the confidentiality obligations should generally be no less than 5 years from the date of disclosure.
content.plain_text: Confidentiality obligations should generally last at least 5 years from the disclosure date.
content.expert_insight: This sets Zebracorp's standard minimum duration for confidentiality, reflecting a balance between long-term protection and practical enforceability.
content.justification: States Zebracorp's preferred duration for confidentiality obligations.
content.implication_company: Ensures a reasonable period of protection for Zebracorp's confidential information.
content.implication_supplier: They should expect a minimum 5-year obligation.
content.text: The duration of the confidentiality obligations should generally be no less than 5 years from the date of disclosure.

content.verbatim_text: Shorter time frames should only be accepted if the nature of information to be shared with the supplier/subcontractor is not particularly sensitive.
content.plain_text: Shorter confidentiality periods are only acceptable if the shared information is not highly sensitive.
content.expert_insight: This provides a clear condition for flexibility. It allows for negotiation on duration but ties it directly to the sensitivity of the information, protecting Zebracorp's most valuable assets.
content.justification: Provides a condition for accepting shorter confidentiality durations.
content.implication_company: Allows for flexibility while safeguarding highly sensitive information.
content.implication_supplier: They can only negotiate shorter terms if the information is not deemed sensitive by Zebracorp.
content.text: Shorter time frames should only be accepted if the nature of information to be shared with the supplier/subcontractor is not particularly sensitive.

content.verbatim_text: In exceptional cases where Zebracorp discloses especially sensitive information to its suppliers, we may wish to consider including a penalty or liquidated damages clauses which will impose a monetary penalty on the supplier for any breach of the confidentiality undertakings.
content.plain_text: For exceptionally sensitive information, Zebracorp may consider including penalty or liquidated damages clauses to impose monetary penalties for confidentiality breaches.
content.expert_insight: This suggests a strong deterrent for high-stakes information. Liquidated damages can provide a pre-agreed remedy, simplifying enforcement and signaling the gravity of the information's protection.
content.justification: Suggests a strategic consideration for specific, high-risk scenarios.
content.implication_company: Provides an additional layer of protection and a clearer path to recovery for breaches of highly sensitive information.
content.implication_supplier: They might face pre-defined monetary penalties for breaches in such exceptional cases.
content.source_insight: Zebracorp's strategic consideration for high-risk data.
content.text: In exceptional cases where Zebracorp discloses especially sensitive information to its suppliers, we may wish to consider including a penalty or liquidated damages clauses which will impose a monetary penalty on the supplier for any breach of the confidentiality undertakings.

content.verbatim_text: However, these clauses should never be introduced lightly as we should expect the supplier to balk at such at liquidated damages/penalty provision.
content.plain_text: Penalty or liquidated damages clauses should be used sparingly, as suppliers are likely to resist them.
content.expert_insight: This provides crucial negotiation context. While beneficial for Zebracorp, such clauses are contentious and can complicate negotiations, requiring careful strategic deployment.
content.justification: Offers cautionary advice regarding the use of penalty clauses.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should reserve these clauses for truly exceptional cases to avoid unnecessary negotiation friction.
content.implication_supplier: They are expected to resist such provisions, indicating a potential negotiation challenge.
content.text: However, these clauses should never be introduced lightly as we should expect the supplier to balk at such at liquidated damages/penalty provision.

content.verbatim_text: When using this type of a penalty provision, it is important to ensure that the payment of the penalty/liquidated damages does not relieve the supplier from liability for any other damages or release the supplier from its obligation to continue to honour the confidentiality undertakings.
content.plain_text: If using a penalty clause, ensure it doesn't absolve the supplier from other damages or ongoing confidentiality obligations.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical drafting instruction. The penalty should be an *additional* deterrent/remedy, not a cap or replacement for other liabilities or the continuing duty of confidentiality.
content.justification: Provides specific drafting instruction to safeguard Zebracorp's interests when using penalty clauses.
content.implication_company: Ensures maximum protection by making penalty clauses cumulative with other remedies and ongoing obligations.
content.implication_supplier: They would still be liable for other damages and ongoing confidentiality, even after paying a penalty.
content.source_insight: Zebracorp's drafting instruction for cumulative remedies.
content.text: When using this type of a penalty provision, it is important to ensure that the payment of the penalty/liquidated damages does not relieve the supplier from liability for any other damages or release the supplier from its obligation to continue to honour the confidentiality undertakings.

content.verbatim_text: While it would be common to disclaim liability for indirect or consequential damages in most contracts, in NonDisclosure/Confidentiality Agreements, the losses or damages that may occur could be argued to be indirect or consequential.
content.plain_text: While indirect/consequential damages are often disclaimed in other contracts, losses from confidentiality breaches can be argued as indirect/consequential.
content.expert_insight: This explains the unique nature of damages in confidentiality breaches. What might be considered 'indirect' in other contexts could be the primary damage in a confidentiality breach, making standard disclaimers problematic.
content.justification: Provides context on the nature of damages in confidentiality breaches.
content.implication_company: Helps Zebracorp understand why standard damage disclaimers are inappropriate for confidentiality.
content.implication_supplier: They should be aware that their liability for confidentiality breaches may extend to damages typically considered indirect.
content.text: While it would be common to disclaim liability for indirect or consequential damages in most contracts, in NonDisclosure/Confidentiality Agreements, the losses or damages that may occur could be argued to be indirect or consequential.

content.verbatim_text: For this reason, such a disclaimer is not commonly used in these type of agreements and we should be very careful to accept the exclusion of indirect or consequential damages for breaches of confidentiality.
content.plain_text: Therefore, disclaiming indirect/consequential damages is uncommon in confidentiality agreements, and Zebracorp should be very cautious about accepting such exclusions.
content.expert_insight: This is a strong directive. Accepting such a disclaimer would severely limit Zebracorp's ability to recover for the most significant harms resulting from a confidentiality breach, which are often indirect (e.g., loss of market share, reputational damage).
content.justification: Provides strategic advice and a strong caution against accepting certain exclusions.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must strongly resist any exclusion of indirect/consequential damages for confidentiality breaches to protect its full recovery rights.
content.implication_supplier: They will likely face strong resistance if they propose to exclude indirect/consequential damages for confidentiality breaches.
content.text: For this reason, such a disclaimer is not commonly used in these type of agreements and we should be very careful to accept the exclusion of indirect or consequential damages for breaches of confidentiality.

content.verbatim_text: Residuals clause in non-disclosure agreements usually gives the parties the right to use such other party’s confidential information which is retained in the employees’ unaided memories in non-tangible form (i.e. without reference to any document and without the intent to memorize the information) by those employees who had access to the other party’s confidential information.
content.plain_text: A residuals clause typically allows parties to use confidential information retained in employees' unaided memories, without documentation or intent to memorize.
content.expert_insight: This explains the concept of a 'residuals' clause, which addresses the practical reality that individuals cannot 'un-know' information. It's a complex area balancing protection with practical limitations.
content.justification: Explains the definition and purpose of a residuals clause.
content.implication_company: Understanding this clause is crucial for Zebracorp to assess its implications for both receiving and disclosing information.
content.implication_supplier: They would also benefit from understanding this clause's implications for their employees.
content.source_insight: Explanation of a specific contractual clause.
content.text: Residuals clause in non-disclosure agreements usually gives the parties the right to use such other party’s confidential information which is retained in the employees’ unaided memories in non-tangible form (i.e. without reference to any document and without the intent to memorize the information) by those employees who had access to the other party’s confidential information.

content.verbatim_text: When Zebracorp purchases R&D work and services but does not acquire any deep knowledge of the subcontractor’s own products and trade secrets, Zebracorp should not agree to a residuals clause.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should not agree to a residuals clause when purchasing R&D work/services if it doesn't gain deep knowledge of the subcontractor's products/trade secrets.
content.expert_insight: This is a strategic directive. If Zebracorp is primarily a recipient of services without deep immersion into the subcontractor's IP, a residuals clause could inadvertently grant the subcontractor rights to Zebracorp's own information, or create ambiguity.
content.justification: Provides a specific negotiation stance for Zebracorp regarding residuals clauses.
content.implication_company: Protects Zebracorp from unintended obligations or granting rights to its own information when not necessary.
content.implication_supplier: They might be denied a residuals clause if Zebracorp's engagement is limited.
content.text: When Zebracorp purchases R&D work and services but does not acquire any deep knowledge of the subcontractor’s own products and trade secrets, Zebracorp should not agree to a residuals clause.

content.verbatim_text: However, when Zebracorp is genuinely working/collaborating together with a subcontractor in R&D projects, and has the risk of receiving subcontractor’s proprietary sensitive information which may be difficult to “clean out” of the engineers’ memory, the usage of the residuals clause might be beneficial.
content.plain_text: A residuals clause might be beneficial when Zebracorp genuinely collaborates in R&D projects and risks receiving sensitive subcontractor information that's hard to 'clean out' of engineers' memories.
content.expert_insight: This outlines the specific scenario where a residuals clause *is* beneficial for Zebracorp. It acknowledges the practical difficulty of preventing 'contamination' of its own engineers' knowledge and provides a legal framework to manage it.
content.justification: Provides a strategic consideration for when a residuals clause might be beneficial.
content.implication_company: Allows Zebracorp to manage the risk of 'contamination' of its employees' knowledge when deeply collaborating.
content.implication_supplier: They might find Zebracorp more amenable to a residuals clause in true R&D collaborations.
content.text: However, when Zebracorp is genuinely working/collaborating together with a subcontractor in R&D projects, and has the risk of receiving subcontractor’s proprietary sensitive information which may be difficult to “clean out” of the engineers’ memory, the usage of the residuals clause might be beneficial.

content.verbatim_text: In such (rare) cases, it is recommended to add the following clause covering the use of this residual information: “Residuals” mean information of general nature (including but not limited to ideas, concepts, know-how and techniques) in non-tangible form, which a) may be retained in the unaided human memory (i.e. without reference to any document and without the intent to memorize the information) by persons who have had access to the Confidential Information of the other Party, and b) is of such a nature that the acquisition of it by these employees amounts to no more than an enhancement of the personal knowledge, skill or experience used by them in the exercise of their duties. Either Party shall be free to use for any purpose the Residuals (defined above) resulting from access to or work with other Party’s Confidential Information disclosed hereunder. For the sake of clarity, the right to use Residuals as agreed above does not give the receiving Party the right to use, disclose, publish, or disseminate the source of Residuals, or any license rights under any patents, copyrights or any other intellectual property rights.”
content.plain_text: In rare, collaborative R&D cases, a specific residuals clause should be added, defining residuals as general, non-tangible information retained in unaided memory that enhances personal knowledge, allowing free use of such residuals without granting IP licenses or disclosing the source.
content.expert_insight: This provides a comprehensive, carefully drafted residuals clause. It balances the need for practical use of retained knowledge with strong protections against unauthorized use of the source IP, which is crucial for Zebracorp.
content.justification: Provides a specific clause to be used in certain scenarios.
content.implication_company: Offers a balanced legal framework for managing residual knowledge in deep collaborations.
content.implication_supplier: This is the specific language they would encounter if a residuals clause is deemed beneficial.
content.text: In such (rare) cases, it is recommended to add the following clause covering the use of this residual information: “Residuals” mean information of general nature (including but not limited to ideas, concepts, know-how and techniques) in non-tangible form, which a) may be retained in the unaided human memory (i.e. without reference to any document and without the intent to memorize the information) by persons who have had access to the Confidential Information of the other Party, and b) is of such a nature that the acquisition of it by these employees amounts to no more than an enhancement of the personal knowledge, skill or experience used by them in the exercise of their duties. Either Party shall be free to use for any purpose the Residuals (defined above) resulting from access to or work with other Party’s Confidential Information disclosed hereunder. For the sake of clarity, the right to use Residuals as agreed above does not give the receiving Party the right to use, disclose, publish, or disseminate the source of Residuals, or any license rights under any patents, copyrights or any other intellectual property rights.”

content.verbatim_text: In cases where it is seen as likely that under any (non-disclosure) agreement one party gives feedback to the other party solely relating to such other party’s (i.e. receiving party’s ) products or services, it is recommended to include a feedback clause, which clarifies how the receiving party can use such feedback.
content.plain_text: If feedback on a party's products/services is likely, a feedback clause should be included to clarify how the receiving party can use it.
content.expert_insight: This highlights a proactive measure to manage IP rights related to feedback. Without such a clause, valuable feedback could be claimed by the providing party, creating legal complications.
content.justification: Provides a strategic recommendation for including a feedback clause.
content.implication_company: Ensures Zebracorp can freely use feedback received on its products/services without IP disputes.
content.implication_supplier: They would need to agree on the terms of how their feedback can be used.
content.text: In cases where it is seen as likely that under any (non-disclosure) agreement one party gives feedback to the other party solely relating to such other party’s (i.e. receiving party’s ) products or services, it is recommended to include a feedback clause, which clarifies how the receiving party can use such feedback.

content.verbatim_text: Without a proper feedback clause it might be possible that the first party to assert that the idea/suggestion forming the feedback is the first party’s proprietary and confidential information and the usage of such feedback would amount to breach of the confidentiality agreement (and potentially also an IPR infringement).
content.plain_text: Without a feedback clause, the party providing feedback might claim it as proprietary/confidential, leading to confidentiality breaches or IPR infringement if used.
content.expert_insight: This explains the significant risk of not having a feedback clause. It clarifies how seemingly innocuous feedback can become a source of legal dispute, underscoring the need for explicit contractual terms.
content.justification: Explains the risk associated with not having a feedback clause.
content.implication_company: Highlights the potential legal exposure for Zebracorp if it uses feedback without clear rights.
content.implication_supplier: They might inadvertently create IP issues if they provide feedback without a clear clause.
content.text: Without a proper feedback clause it might be possible that the first party to assert that the idea/suggestion forming the feedback is the first party’s proprietary and confidential information and the usage of such feedback would amount to breach of the confidentiality agreement (and potentially also an IPR infringement).

content.verbatim_text: Usually the party requesting a right to use feedback will also request a full-blown license to use such feedback.
content.plain_text: The party seeking to use feedback typically requests a broad license for its use.
content.expert_insight: This notes a common negotiation position. While a broad license is desirable for the receiving party, Zebracorp's subsequent advice indicates a need to limit this for its own protection.
content.justification: Provides information on common requests regarding feedback licenses.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should anticipate requests for broad licenses but be prepared to limit them.
content.implication_supplier: They might expect to receive a broad license for feedback they provide.
content.text: Usually the party requesting a right to use feedback will also request a full-blown license to use such feedback.

content.verbatim_text: However, Zebracorp should not agree to any broad or open licenses but the license to use feedback must be strictly confined to general comments on the functionality of the products in question, and must not include any Zebracorp intellectual property rights.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should reject broad feedback licenses, limiting them strictly to general comments on product functionality and excluding any Zebracorp IP rights.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical protective measure. Zebracorp must ensure that granting a license to use feedback does not inadvertently grant rights to its underlying IP or allow the feedback to be used beyond its intended scope.
content.justification: Provides a specific negotiation stance for Zebracorp regarding feedback licenses.
content.implication_company: Protects Zebracorp's core IP while allowing for the practical use of feedback.
content.implication_supplier: They will face limitations on the scope of the license they receive for feedback.
content.source_insight: Zebracorp's negotiation directive for IP protection.
content.text: However, Zebracorp should not agree to any broad or open licenses but the license to use feedback must be strictly confined to general comments on the functionality of the products in question, and must not include any Zebracorp intellectual property rights.

content.verbatim_text: Under any projects where a party likely gives feedback of the other party’s products or services, in particular in cases where the subcontractor gives us feedback about Zebracorp products or services (other than for which we pay for anyway) we should add the following clause: “The parties may, but are not obliged to, propose ideas or suggestions to each other relating to the other party’s products and services (“Feedback”). The party receiving Feedback shall be entitled to use and incorporate such Feedback in receiving party’s products/services, at the Feedback receiving party’s sole risk and without any obligation to pay any royalties or other compensation or consideration to the other party for such use/incorporation; provided however that the Feedback is provided “as is” basis without warranties of any kind, and no license, express or implied, is granted by the Feedback giving party to the Feedback receiving party under this clause.”
content.plain_text: In projects where feedback is likely, especially from subcontractors on Zebracorp products, Zebracorp should add a clause allowing the receiving party to use feedback 'as is' without royalties, warranties, or implied IP licenses.
content.expert_insight: This provides a comprehensive, protective feedback clause for Zebracorp. It ensures Zebracorp can freely use feedback without incurring obligations (royalties, warranties) or inadvertently acquiring IP licenses from the feedback provider.
content.justification: Provides a specific clause to be used for feedback in certain scenarios.
content.implication_company: Secures Zebracorp's right to use feedback on its products/services without additional cost or IP encumbrances.
content.implication_supplier: Their feedback would be provided 'as is' and could be used by Zebracorp without compensation or granting IP rights.
content.text: Under any projects where a party likely gives feedback of the other party’s products or services, in particular in cases where the subcontractor gives us feedback about Zebracorp products or services (other than for which we pay for anyway) we should add the following clause: “The parties may, but are not obliged to, propose ideas or suggestions to each other relating to the other party’s products and services (“Feedback”). The party receiving Feedback shall be entitled to use and incorporate such Feedback in receiving party’s products/services, at the Feedback receiving party’s sole risk and without any obligation to pay any royalties or other compensation or consideration to the other party for such use/incorporation; provided however that the Feedback is provided “as is” basis without warranties of any kind, and no license, express or implied, is granted by the Feedback giving party to the Feedback receiving party under this clause.”

content.verbatim_text: Please note that where the subcontractor is a competitor of Zebracorp, either in business or product level, Zebracorp may bear the risk of getting “contaminated” by receiving such subcontractor’s confidential information, and therefore separate clean teams may need to be created.
content.plain_text: If a subcontractor is a competitor, Zebracorp risks 'contamination' from their confidential information, potentially requiring the creation of separate 'clean teams'.
content.expert_insight: This highlights a significant antitrust and IP risk. 'Contamination' refers to the inadvertent use of a competitor's confidential information, which can lead to legal challenges. Clean teams are a common mitigation strategy.
content.justification: Provides important risk awareness and a potential mitigation strategy.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must be aware of and mitigate the risk of 'contamination' when dealing with competitors.
content.implication_supplier: They should understand that Zebracorp may implement strict measures like clean teams due to competitive concerns.
content.text: Please note that where the subcontractor is a competitor of Zebracorp, either in business or product level, Zebracorp may bear the risk of getting “contaminated” by receiving such subcontractor’s confidential information, and therefore separate clean teams may need to be created.

content.verbatim_text: See the guidance: https://www.zebracorp.com/guidance
content.plain_text: Refer to the internal guidance document at the provided URL for more information.
content.expert_insight: This is an internal instruction to consult a more detailed resource, indicating that the topic of 'clean teams' is complex and has dedicated internal guidelines.
content.justification: Directs the user to an internal resource for further information.
content.implication_company: Requires internal personnel to consult specific Zebracorp guidance for handling competitor-related risks.
content.implication_supplier: Not directly applicable to the supplier, but indicates Zebracorp's internal processes.
content.text: See the guidance: https://www.zebracorp.com/guidance

content.verbatim_text: “Residuals” mean information of general nature (including but not limited to ideas, concepts, know-how and techniques) in non-tangible form, which a) may be retained in the unaided human memory (i.e. without reference to any document and without the intent to memorize the information) by persons who have had access to the Confidential Information of the other Party, and b) is of such a nature that the acquisition of it by these employees amounts to no more than an enhancement of the personal knowledge, skill or experience used by them in the exercise of their duties. Either Party shall be free to use for any purpose the Residuals (defined above) resulting from access to or work with other Party’s Confidential Information disclosed hereunder. For the sake of clarity, the right to use Residuals as agreed above does not give the receiving Party the right to use, disclose, publish, or disseminate the source of Residuals, or any license rights under any patents, copyrights or any other intellectual property rights.”
content.plain_text: Residuals refer to general, non-tangible information (such as ideas, concepts, know-how, and techniques) that individuals retain in their unaided memory (without reference to documents or intent to memorize) after accessing another party's Confidential Information. This retained information must only enhance their personal knowledge, skill, or experience. Either party is free to use such Residuals, but this right does not permit using, disclosing, publishing the source, or granting any intellectual property licenses.
content.expert_insight: This definition is crucial in R&D contexts, allowing parties to leverage general knowledge gained from exposure to confidential information without being unduly restricted, provided it's not a direct copy or intentional memorization. It explicitly limits the scope of use to prevent disclosure of the source or implied IP licenses.
content.text: “Residuals” mean information of general nature (including but not limited to ideas, concepts, know-how and techniques) in non-tangible form, which a) may be retained in the unaided human memory (i.e. without reference to any document and without the intent to memorize the information) by persons who have had access to the Confidential Information of the other Party, and b) is of such a nature that the acquisition of it by these employees amounts to no more than an enhancement of the personal knowledge, skill or experience used by them in the exercise of their duties. Either Party shall be free to use for any purpose the Residuals (defined above) resulting from access to or work with other Party’s Confidential Information disclosed hereunder. For the sake of clarity, the right to use Residuals as agreed above does not give the receiving Party the right to use, disclose, publish, or disseminate the source of Residuals, or any license rights under any patents, copyrights or any other intellectual property rights.”

content.verbatim_text: “The parties may, but are not obliged to, propose ideas or suggestions to each other relating to the other party’s products and services (“Feedback”). The party receiving Feedback shall be entitled to use and incorporate such Feedback in receiving party’s products/services, at the Feedback receiving party’s sole risk and without any obligation to pay any royalties or other compensation or consideration to the other party for such use/incorporation; provided however that the Feedback is provided “as is” basis without warranties of any kind, and no license, express or implied, is granted by the Feedback giving party to the Feedback receiving party under this clause.”

The party receiving Feedback is entitled to use and incorporate it into their products/services at their own risk, without any obligation to pay royalties or compensation. The Feedback is provided 'as is' without warranties, and no express or implied license is granted by the party providing the Feedback.
content.expert_insight: This clause clarifies the terms of use for feedback, preventing future disputes over ownership or compensation. It's important to ensure that the license to use feedback is strictly confined to general comments on functionality and does not inadvertently grant rights to any underlying intellectual property of the feedback-giving party.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp contract templates typically list the following four exclusions: i.) information that is in the public domain at the time of disclosure or later becomes part of the public domain through no fault of the receiving party; and ii.) information that was previously known to the receiving party; and iii.) information that is disclosed to the receiving party by a third party who did not obtain such information, directly or indirectly, from the disclosing party; and information that was independently developed by the receiving party.

content.verbatim_text: In any event such right to share confidential information to third parties should be conditional on the receiving party accepting responsibility for any unauthorized disclosure or use of the confidential information by such third party to the same extent, as if it had been its own unauthorized disclosure or use of information.

content.expert_insight: This 'pass-through liability' clause is vital to ensure that the original receiving party remains accountable for the actions of any downstream recipients, providing a strong incentive for careful management.

content.justification: This ensures accountability for confidential information even when it is sub-disclosed, preventing a loophole where the original receiving party might disclaim responsibility.
content.implication_company: If Zebracorp is the receiving party, it assumes full liability for any breaches by its third parties, requiring rigorous vetting and contractual agreements with them.

content.text: In any event such right to share confidential information to third parties should be conditional on the receiving party accepting responsibility for any unauthorized disclosure or use of the confidential information by such third party to the same extent, as if it had been its own unauthorized disclosure or use of information.

content.verbatim_text: “Residuals” mean information of general nature (including but not limited to ideas, concepts, know-how and techniques) in non-tangible form, which a) may be retained in the unaided human memory (i.e. without reference to any document and without the intent to memorize the information) by persons who have had access to the Confidential Information of the other Party, and b) is of such a nature that the acquisition of it by these employees amounts to no more than an enhancement of the personal knowledge, skill or experience used by them in the exercise of their duties.

content.verbatim_text: Should the subcontractor categorically reject the foregoing compromise proposal, and should Zebracorp subsequently be forced to accept an obligation to summarize all verbal disclosures into written format, Zebracorp should appoint a single point of contact (a so called “gatekeeper”) to disclose any Zebracorp confidential information under the respective contract, and agree that any and all disclosures and receiving of confidential information may take place only through this nominated contact person.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp contract templates typically list the following four exclusions: i.) information that is in the public domain at the time of disclosure or later becomes part of the public domain through no fault of the receiving party; and ii.) information that was previously known to the receiving party; and iii.) information that is disclosed to the receiving party by a third party who did not obtain such information, directly or indirectly, from the disclosing party; and information that was independently developed by the receiving party.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's standard contract templates exclude information that is: i) publicly available or becomes so without fault of the recipient; ii) already known to the recipient; iii) received from a third party not bound by confidentiality to the discloser; and iv) independently developed by the recipient.
content.expert_insight: These are common and widely accepted exclusions, providing clear boundaries for what is not considered confidential. They protect the receiving party from being unduly restricted by information they already possess or could legitimately acquire.

content.verbatim_text: As for point vi.) above, it is customary to specify that the disclosure by law or court order is only allowed if before making such disclosure, the party planning to make such disclosure shall, to the extent permitted by applicable law give the other party a reasonable opportunity to intervene and/or take action to seek confidential handling of such information and reasonably cooperate with the other party, to seek confidential handling of such information.

content.justification: To ensure the supplier remains fully accountable for all damages and ongoing obligations, beyond just the penalty amount.
content.implication_company: Protects Zebracorp's right to pursue full damages and continued compliance, even after a penalty is paid.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier's liability is not limited to the penalty amount, and confidentiality obligations persist.
content.text: When using this type of a penalty provision, it is important to ensure that the payment of the penalty/liquidated damages does not relieve the supplier from liability for any other damages or release the supplier from its obligation to continue to honour the confidentiality undertakings.

content.verbatim_text: While it would be common to disclaim liability for indirect or consequential damages in most contracts, in NonDisclosure/Confidentiality Agreements, the losses or damages that may occur could be argued to be indirect or consequential.
content.plain_text: While indirect/consequential damages disclaimers are common in most contracts, losses from NDA/confidentiality breaches can often be classified as indirect or consequential.
content.expert_insight: This clarifies why standard contract clauses might not apply to NDAs. The very nature of confidentiality breaches often results in damages that fall into the 'indirect' or 'consequential' categories.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: While it would be common to disclaim liability for indirect or consequential damages in most contracts, in NonDisclosure/Confidentiality Agreements, the losses or damages that may occur could be argued to be indirect or consequential.

content.verbatim_text: For this reason, such a disclaimer is not commonly used in these type of agreements and we should be very careful to accept the exclusion of indirect or consequential damages for breaches of confidentiality.
content.plain_text: Therefore, disclaimers for indirect or consequential damages are rarely used in confidentiality agreements, and Zebracorp should be extremely cautious about accepting such exclusions for confidentiality breaches.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical directive. Accepting such an exclusion would severely limit Zebracorp's ability to recover damages for the most common and often largest losses resulting from a confidentiality breach. It should be strongly resisted.
content.conditions: When negotiating Non-Disclosure/Confidentiality Agreements.
content.justification: Losses from confidentiality breaches are often indirect or consequential, and excluding them would severely limit recovery.
content.implication_company: Accepting such an exclusion could leave Zebracorp unable to recover significant damages from a breach.
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: For this reason, such a disclaimer is not commonly used in these type of agreements and we should be very careful to accept the exclusion of indirect or consequential damages for breaches of confidentiality.

content.verbatim_text: Residuals clause in non-disclosure agreements usually gives the parties the right to use such other party’s confidential information which is retained in the employees’ unaided memories in non-tangible form (i.e. without reference to any document and without the intent to memorize the information) by those employees who had access to the other party’s confidential information.
content.plain_text: A residuals clause in NDAs typically grants parties the right to use confidential information retained in employees' unaided memories (non-tangible, without intent to memorize) after having access to it.
content.expert_insight: This describes the purpose of a residuals clause: to address the practical reality that employees cannot simply 'un-know' information, allowing for its incidental use if not deliberately memorized or referenced.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: Residuals clause in non-disclosure agreements usually gives the parties the right to use such other party’s confidential information which is retained in the employees’ unaided memories in non-tangible form (i.e. without reference to any document and without the intent to memorize the information) by those employees who had access to the other party’s confidential information.

content.verbatim_text: When Zebracorp purchases R&D work and services but does not acquire any deep knowledge of the subcontractor’s own products and trade secrets, Zebracorp should not agree to a residuals clause.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should not agree to a residuals clause when purchasing R&D work/services if it does not gain deep knowledge of the subcontractor's products/trade secrets.
content.expert_insight: This is a defensive stance. If Zebracorp is merely a recipient of R&D services without deeply integrating the subcontractor's core IP, a residuals clause would unduly benefit the subcontractor without reciprocal value.
content.conditions: When Zebracorp purchases R&D work/services without acquiring deep knowledge of the subcontractor's products/trade secrets.
content.justification: To avoid granting the subcontractor rights to Zebracorp's information without reciprocal benefit.
content.implication_company: Protects Zebracorp from potential unintended use of its own confidential information by the subcontractor.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier would not gain the right to use residual information from Zebracorp in this scenario.
content.text: When Zebracorp purchases R&D work and services but does not acquire any deep knowledge of the subcontractor’s own products and trade secrets, Zebracorp should not agree to a residuals clause.

content.verbatim_text: However, when Zebracorp is genuinely working/collaborating together with a subcontractor in R&D projects, and has the risk of receiving subcontractor’s proprietary sensitive information which may be difficult to “clean out” of the engineers’ memory, the usage of the residuals clause might be beneficial.
content.plain_text: A residuals clause might be beneficial when Zebracorp actively collaborates with a subcontractor on R&D projects and risks receiving proprietary sensitive information difficult for engineers to forget.
content.expert_insight: This outlines a scenario where a residuals clause can be mutually beneficial, acknowledging the practical difficulty of 'unlearning' integrated knowledge in deep R&D collaborations.
content.conditions: When Zebracorp is genuinely collaborating in R&D projects and risks receiving subcontractor's proprietary sensitive information that may be difficult to 'clean out' of engineers' memories.
content.justification: To address the practical reality of knowledge retention in deep R&D collaborations.
content.implication_company: Provides Zebracorp with a legal basis to use 'residual' knowledge gained from collaboration, reducing potential liability.
content.implication_supplier: Allows the supplier to use 'residual' knowledge from Zebracorp's information.
content.text: However, when Zebracorp is genuinely working/collaborating together with a subcontractor in R&D projects, and has the risk of receiving subcontractor’s proprietary sensitive information which may be difficult to “clean out” of the engineers’ memory, the usage of the residuals clause might be beneficial.

content.verbatim_text: “Residuals” mean information of general nature (including but not limited to ideas, concepts, know-how and techniques) in non-tangible form, which a) may be retained in the unaided human memory (i.e. without reference to any document and without the intent to memorize the information) by persons who have had access to the Confidential Information of the other Party, and b) is of such a nature that the acquisition of it by these employees amounts to no more than an enhancement of the personal knowledge, skill or experience used by them in the exercise of their duties.
content.plain_text: “Residuals” refers to non-tangible, general information (ideas, concepts, know-how, techniques) retained in human memory without aid or intent to memorize, by individuals who accessed the other party's confidential information, where its acquisition only enhances their personal knowledge, skill, or experience.
content.expert_insight: This is a precise definition of 'residuals', crucial for distinguishing between legitimately retained general knowledge and protected confidential information that should not be used.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: “Residuals” mean information of general nature (including but not limited to ideas, concepts, know-how and techniques) in non-tangible form, which a) may be retained in the unaided human memory (i.e. without reference to any document and without the intent to memorize the information) by persons who have had access to the Confidential Information of the other Party, and b) is of such a nature that the acquisition of it by these employees amounts to no more than an enhancement of the personal knowledge, skill or experience used by them in the exercise of their duties.

content.verbatim_text: Either Party shall be free to use for any purpose the Residuals (defined above) resulting from access to or work with other Party’s Confidential Information disclosed hereunder. For the sake of clarity, the right to use Residuals as agreed above does not give the receiving Party the right to use, disclose, publish, or disseminate the source of Residuals, or any license rights under any patents, copyrights or any other intellectual property rights.
content.plain_text: Either party may use 'Residuals' for any purpose, but this right does not extend to using, disclosing, publishing, or disseminating the source of Residuals, nor does it grant any intellectual property license rights.
content.expert_insight: This clause grants broad usage rights for 'residuals' while carefully carving out protections for the original source and underlying intellectual property, preventing unintended IP transfer.
content.conditions: When a residuals clause is included in the agreement.
content.justification: To clarify the scope of use for 'residuals' and protect underlying intellectual property rights.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can freely use 'residual' knowledge without fear of breach, but cannot exploit the source's IP.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier can freely use 'residual' knowledge, but cannot exploit Zebracorp's IP or disclose its source.
content.text: Either Party shall be free to use for any purpose the Residuals (defined above) resulting from access to or work with other Party’s Confidential Information disclosed hereunder. For the sake of clarity, the right to use Residuals as agreed above does not give the receiving Party the right to use, disclose, publish, or disseminate the source of Residuals, or any license rights under any patents, copyrights or any other intellectual property rights.

content.verbatim_text: In cases where it is seen as likely that under any (non-disclosure) agreement one party gives feedback to the other party solely relating to such other party’s (i.e. receiving party’s ) products or services, it is recommended to include a feedback clause, which clarifies how the receiving party can use such feedback.
content.plain_text: If feedback on a party's products/services is likely to be provided under an agreement, a feedback clause should be included to clarify how the receiving party can use it.
content.expert_insight: A feedback clause is important to preemptively address ownership and usage rights of suggestions, preventing future disputes over intellectual property or confidentiality.
content.conditions: When it is likely that one party will provide feedback to the other party regarding their products or services.
content.justification: To prevent potential claims of proprietary information or IPR infringement regarding feedback.
content.implication_company: Ensures clarity on how Zebracorp can use feedback received from a supplier, or how a supplier can use feedback from Zebracorp.
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: In cases where it is seen as likely that under any (non-disclosure) agreement one party gives feedback to the other party solely relating to such other party’s (i.e. receiving party’s ) products or services, it is recommended to include a feedback clause, which clarifies how the receiving party can use such feedback.

content.verbatim_text: Without a proper feedback clause it might be possible that the first party to assert that the idea/suggestion forming the feedback is the first party’s proprietary and confidential information and the usage of such feedback would amount to breach of the confidentiality agreement (and potentially also an IPR infringement).
content.plain_text: Without a feedback clause, the feedback provider might claim the ideas/suggestions are their proprietary and confidential information, leading to confidentiality breaches or IPR infringement claims if used.
content.expert_insight: This clearly articulates the risk of not having a feedback clause, emphasizing the potential for disputes over ownership and use of ideas shared as feedback.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: Without a proper feedback clause it might be possible that the first party to assert that the idea/suggestion forming the feedback is the first party’s proprietary and confidential information and the usage of such feedback would amount to breach of the confidentiality agreement (and potentially also an IPR infringement).

content.verbatim_text: Usually the party requesting a right to use feedback will also request a full-blown license to use such feedback.
content.plain_text: Parties seeking to use feedback typically request a comprehensive license for its use.
content.expert_insight: This highlights a common negotiation point, where the recipient of feedback often seeks broad rights, which Zebracorp should be wary of.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: Usually the party requesting a right to use feedback will also request a full-blown license to use such feedback.

content.verbatim_text: However, Zebracorp should not agree to any broad or open licenses but the license to use feedback must be strictly confined to general comments on the functionality of the products in question, and must not include any Zebracorp intellectual property rights.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should reject broad licenses for feedback, limiting usage to general comments on product functionality and excluding any Zebracorp intellectual property rights.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical protective stance for Zebracorp. It ensures that feedback doesn't inadvertently grant rights to Zebracorp's core IP or allow its broader exploitation beyond the specific functional comments.
content.conditions: When negotiating feedback clauses.
content.justification: To protect Zebracorp's intellectual property rights and prevent unintended broad licenses.
content.implication_company: Prevents the erosion of Zebracorp's IP through feedback clauses.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier's use of feedback would be strictly limited, and they would not gain rights to Zebracorp's IP.
content.text: However, Zebracorp should not agree to any broad or open licenses but the license to use feedback must be strictly confined to general comments on the functionality of the products in question, and must not include any Zebracorp intellectual property rights.

content.verbatim_text: “Feedback” means ideas or suggestions to each other relating to the other party’s products and services.
content.plain_text: “Feedback” is defined as ideas or suggestions exchanged between parties concerning the other party’s products and services.
content.expert_insight: This provides a clear, concise definition of 'Feedback' within the context of the proposed clause.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: “Feedback” means ideas or suggestions to each other relating to the other party’s products and services.

content.verbatim_text: The parties may, but are not obliged to, propose ideas or suggestions to each other relating to the other party’s products and services (“Feedback”). The party receiving Feedback shall be entitled to use and incorporate such Feedback in receiving party’s products/services, at the Feedback receiving party’s sole risk and without any obligation to pay any royalties or other compensation or consideration to the other party for such use/incorporation; provided however that the Feedback is provided “as is” basis without warranties of any kind, and no license, express or implied, is granted by the Feedback giving party to the Feedback receiving party under this clause.
content.plain_text: Parties may provide feedback on each other's products/services, but are not obliged to. The receiving party can use and incorporate this feedback at its own risk, without royalties or compensation, provided the feedback is 'as is' without warranties, and no IP license is granted by the feedback provider.
content.expert_insight: This clause establishes a 'no obligation, no compensation, no warranty, no IP license' framework for feedback, protecting the feedback provider from liability and the recipient from future claims, while allowing for product improvement.
content.conditions: Under any projects where a party is likely to give feedback on the other party’s products or services, especially when a subcontractor gives feedback about Zebracorp products/services (other than paid-for feedback).
content.justification: To clarify rights and obligations regarding feedback, prevent IPR infringement claims, and ensure Zebracorp can use feedback without additional cost or liability.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can use received feedback freely for its products/services without incurring royalties or granting IP rights to the feedback provider.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier can provide feedback without obligation and without granting Zebracorp an IP license for the feedback itself.
content.text: The parties may, but are not obliged to, propose ideas or suggestions to each other relating to the other party’s products and services (“Feedback”). The party receiving Feedback shall be entitled to use and incorporate such Feedback in receiving party’s products/services, at the Feedback receiving party’s sole risk and without any obligation to pay any royalties or other compensation or consideration to the other party for such use/incorporation; provided however that the Feedback is provided “as is” basis without warranties of any kind, and no license, express or implied, is granted by the Feedback giving party to the Feedback receiving party under this clause.

content.verbatim_text: Please note that where the subcontractor is a competitor of Zebracorp, either in business or product level, Zebracorp may bear the risk of getting “contaminated” by receiving such subcontractor’s confidential information, and therefore separate clean teams may need to be created.
content.plain_text: If a subcontractor is a Zebracorp competitor, there's a risk of 'contamination' from receiving their confidential information, potentially necessitating separate 'clean teams'.
content.expert_insight: This highlights the 'contamination risk' in competitive scenarios, where receiving a competitor's confidential information could inadvertently lead to its misuse or allegations of misuse, requiring strict information barriers like clean teams.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Zebracorp faces a risk of 'contamination' and may need to implement costly 'clean team' structures to manage information flow.
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: Please note that where the subcontractor is a competitor of Zebracorp, either in business or product level, Zebracorp may bear the risk of getting “contaminated” by receiving such subcontractor’s confidential information, and therefore separate clean teams may need to be created.
